column3: I actually met John Astin::: who plays Gomez in the original and his wife. He was great-\-\I was working late night in a supermarket in Wellington New Zealand in 1995 when he was filming Peter Jackson's "The Frighteners". He got a big kick out of me asking "Sorry::: but aren't you Gomez from the Addams Family?". He was amazed that a kid on the other side of the world::: who obviously wasn't born when the show was on would recognise him. I said that I hadn't watched much of the show::: but I had played the pinball games. I left my job of stacking coke bottles and helped them find what they were looking for.

column1:
Rising inflation has emerged as the Achilles‚Äô heel of the U.S. economic recovery. Itay Goldstein of The Wharton School talks with Penn Today about the inflation report and the principles of supply and demand.

PENNTODAY.UPENN.EDU
What's behind the rise in prices? | Penn Today
column3: an overwhelming resistance from a sub-group within the United States to prioritize the needs of humanity over the greed is what serves as a pillar to the inflation. the other nice words are just that. It does not take a Wharton finance professor to articulate what is clear at the spiritual and moral levels. However::: we thank the behavioral scientist for illuminating a point for the stiff-necked in ways that they can process.
column4:
How would you describe inflation in food and energy?

The Professor's response: You saw it in some types of food::: but not all. And again::: and I think that when you saw it::: you can use the same kind of framework of supply and demand to explain it. With food::: it‚Äôs not like you had pent-up demand::: which is clearly something that you had with cars and with flying::: for example::: airfare. For these::: you had pent-up demand. People did not consume so much of it::: and then they wanted to do it and then supply didn‚Äôt catch up::: so you see prices going up. I think with food::: it‚Äôs not like all of a sudden demand was spiking. A lot of it::: if you did see price increases::: would be coming from supply disruptions. And the supply disruptions are really across the board. And a lot of it is related to the pandemic. Commentary: (Federal-level Economic Research spoke to the differentiated spike in food prices::: which show further that the organic fresh produce witnessed a short-term dip in price valuation in no small part because 1) the free food being delivered to the poor was largely dairy subsidized by the same system that is keeping the dairy::: corn::: and soy industries afloat::: 2) people in the U.S. display a propensity to consume less healthy food::: 3) abysmal treatment of immigrants who in the Southern and Western region of the country (the regions producing the overwhelming majority of U.S. grown food) was used as a deflective point in national politics that still show a preponderantly predominate predisposition to prioritize the ideologies of a statistical minority within whom there are members with a monetary advantage over the statistical majority.) So::: YES a lot of it was related to CVD. Fewer U.S. nationals and residents want to do manual labor::: but people still want to eat and to travel. So::: LOGICALLY::: there will be an increase in price when demands haven't really changed::: but the structures in place to provide for people's convenience get disrupted.

This year::: more than any before::: we look forward to the start of classes and our joyful pre-semester programs and events. We want to update everyone::: in light of the ongoing pandemic::: about our progress and the measures we are taking to keep our community safe and healthy.

Consistent with the June 1 message to the community::: the University requires every member of our community to provide proof of vaccination::: since vaccines remain our safest and most effective defense against COVID-19 and its variants.

In accordance with the guidance of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for areas with high transmission rates::: we are now requiring::: effective immediately::: that all members of the Penn community and visitors wear masks while indoors in public or shared spaces. Exceptions to the masking requirement include single occupancy offices and shared spaces where 6-foot distancing can be maintained::: with roommates in our college house suites/rooms::: and by permission in instructional settings for pedagogical reasons. In addition::: we are instituting a required twice-a-week testing program for members of our community who are not vaccinated or choose not to report their vaccination information.

Full statement linked below.

PENNTODAY.UPENN.EDU
A message to the Penn community about campus readiness for the fall semester | Penn Today

column3:
HOW TO OVERCOME VOTER SUPPRESSION
On this July 4th::: a day symbolic of democratic ideals::: I‚Äôd like to suggest the best way to overcome voter suppression. It‚Äôs so simple that it‚Äôs odd it hasn‚Äôt been widely discussed. Just make Election Day a DE FACTO holiday::: no need for an act of Congress. This can be done in several ways: by the will of the people and the support of state and local government::: labor unions::: big business::: and most employers::: and by Executive action by President Biden.
Most people who don‚Äôt vote in person are just worried about losing a day‚Äôs pay or don‚Äôt have time to wait on a long line after work. State and local governments can declare local holidays or closings for election day or give their employees the day off. President Biden::: as chief executive::: should declare a holiday for Federal workers and contractors::: or even invoke executive action as an emergency power. Big corporations such as Walmart and Amazon should give workers the day off. Labor unions should make it an issue in their contracts. School boards should close schools for the day. The list goes on::: and I‚Äôm not an expert::: but an average person can probably add a few options to this list. As for the cost to employers for another paid holiday or to employees for an unpaid day off::: that is a silly issue altogether. There are so many variations in hours per day::: personal or vacation days::: compensatory time::: etc.::: that would
make the problem of cost not relevant or at least not material as the price of saving democracy.
Let‚Äôs just do this.

Statement from Scott Bok on nomination of Penn President Amy Gutmann to be United States Ambassador to Germany

No one is more deserving of this recognition than Amy Gutmann. She is one of the most highly regarded academic leaders in the world and has led the University of Pennsylvania to new heights of eminence. Amy has been a superb President for Penn and we have total confidence that she will remain fully focused on advancing Penn‚Äôs agenda until the conclusion of her time at the University.

Knowing that Amy planned to conclude her Presidency about a year from now after her eighteenth year of leading the University::: the Board had already begun its transition planning and we will provide details on that to the University community in the near future. As Amy has said many times herself::: we have an exceptional leadership team at Penn::: so we are confident that the transition will go smoothly.

President Biden has made a brilliant choice in nominating her for this critical role in American foreign policy. We wish her great success and know that::: subject to confirmation::: she will be an outstanding Ambassador to Germany.

PENNTODAY.UPENN.EDU
Statement from Scott Bok on nomination of Penn President Amy Gutmann to be Ambassador to Germany | Penn Today

column1:
A message to the Penn community on my nomination to serve as United States Ambassador to Germany::: from President Amy Gutmann

Earlier today President Biden nominated me to serve as United States Ambassador to the Federal Republic of Germany. I cannot overstate what a meaningful and extraordinary honor it is to be nominated by the President for this important position of service to our country.

I have previously signaled my plans to conclude my Presidency of Penn at the end of my 18th year::: next June. I will continue to avidly work as Penn President until then or the time when there is a Senate confirmation. I have had conversations with the leadership of our Board of Trustees and we all can rest assured that they are planning for a smooth transition.

I will keep you posted as this process proceeds. I wish you a restful summer as we look forward to the fall and our joyful return to on-campus operations.
To read my full message to the Penn community::: visit Penn Today at the link below.

PENNTODAY.UPENN.EDU
A message to the Penn community on my nomination to serve as United States Ambassador to Germany | Penn Today

A message to the Penn community regarding Juneteenth

Juneteenth marks the 156th anniversary of the date when enslaved people in Texas finally received word that President Lincoln had signed the Emancipation Proclamation more than two and a half years earlier. As our country and University continue to reckon with and work to address the systemic racism and discrimination that are the legacy of slavery::: Penn should and will redouble its efforts to foster justice and equity.

Tomorrow::: in commemoration of this important event in US history::: the University is sponsoring a keynote address with Dr. Ibram X. Kendi who will be interviewed by Wharton Dean Erika James at noon. In addition::: a list of Juneteenth resources may be found at https://faculty.upenn.edu/events/juneteenth/.

The University is offering School and Center leadership flexibility to grant early release or time for reflection tomorrow afternoon for those members of our community who wish to reflect upon the significance of the holiday. The academic calendar has summer session I classes scheduled for June 18. Instructors who elect to hold class should not penalize students who choose not to participate. In the coming year::: we look forward to recognizing this new Federal holiday as part of the University academic calendar.

PENNTODAY.UPENN.EDU
A message to the Penn community regarding Juneteenth | Penn Today

Humans often cooperate::: but ample research has shown that they‚Äôre conditionally cooperative; that is::: they are far more likely to cooperate with those who they consider ‚Äúgood.‚Äù When they don‚Äôt know someone personally::: they may rely on systems that monitor and broadcast reputations.

Using a mathematical model::: Penn Arts & Sciences‚Äô Joshua Plotkin::: Arunas Radvilavicius::: and Taylor Kessinger found that public monitoring systems can be designed to encourage cooperation and to promote adherence to their reputational assessments.

tical and Sci-Fi Works
Young people from any country::: of any nationalities aged 16 to 26 are invited until May 31::: 2021 to register and submit a work for the competition - - http://
www.futurible.sp
ace/en/project/
horizon-2021/
THE COMPETITION IS HELD IN TWO NOMINATIONS:
ÔÅ∂ For the best scientific article::: research::: scientific-prac
tical work::: reflecting the scientific vision of the future of the planet and humanity at the turn of 2100 and the prospects for the development of various scenarios:::
ÔÅ∂ For the best Sci-fi work - sci-fi story::: essay::: reportage::: journalism::: etc. describing imaginary innovative and original ideas::: fantastic events::: phenomena::: processes and future prospects at the turn of the year 2100::: giving them a scientific explanation:::
and also offering the best solutions aimed at:
- reducing the vulnerability of humanity in the face of future pandemics;
- creation of prerequisites and mechanisms in any spheres for the development and strengthening of mankind's resilience to possible future challenges;
- the formation of a future in which the authors of the works would like to live on their own::: and which::: in their opinion::: will meet the needs of the present and the needs of future generations.
THE PROFILE DIRECTIONS:
ÔÉò Future of the humankind
ÔÉò Future of the world
ÔÉò Future of science::: knowledge management and innovation
ÔÉò Future of AI::: digital environment::: bionics::: and other key technologies
ÔÉò Future of the economy::: business and financial sphere
ÔÉò Future of the Earth's ecosystem
ÔÉò Future of energetics
ÔÉò Future of human life
COMPETITION WINNERS GET FREE RIGHT:
- participation in the forum ‚ÄúIMAGE OF THE FUTURE THAT WE WANT: FORESIGHT 2100‚Äù in Moscow in August 2021::: where diplomas will be awarded;
- to present your works on the Internet at: http://
www.futurible.sp
ace/en/winners/
GRAND PRIX-title is awarded to the best participant in each of the two nominations that and will be announced on the forum.
CERTIFICATES in PDF format will be received by all participants.
DIPLOMAS will be awarded to all winners.
The working languages of the Project are Russian and English.

column1:
Statement regarding human remains recovered from the MOVE home
from Amy Gutmann::: President and Wendell Pritchett::: Provost

We were profoundly disturbed to learn this past week that human remains::: provided to a faculty member by the medical examiner many decades ago in an effort to identify a victim from the 1985 bombing of the MOVE house::: had been kept at the Penn Museum for much of that time. Simply said::: this was insensitive::: unprofessional and unacceptable.

An official apology has been extended to the Africa family by the Museum and the University::: and the Museum is currently working to return the remains to the family. In our judgment::: it is imperative that we bring in an outside investigator who can examine how this unfolded and provide us with a complete report on what transpired. To this end::: we have hired attorneys Joe Tucker and Carl Singley of the Tucker Law Group to investigate how the remains came into the possession of the Museum and what transpired with them for nearly four decades. We will share this report with the community and use its findings to help us ensure that nothing of this nature is repeated in the future.

PENNTODAY.UPENN.EDU
Statement regarding human remains recovered from the MOVE home | Penn Today

column1:
The Penn Museum and the University of Pennsylvania apologize to the Africa family and to our community for allowing human remains recovered from the MOVE house to be used for research and teaching::: and for retaining the remains for far too long.

The Philadelphia community has experienced profound emotional distress as a result of the recent news that the remains from the horrific 1985 bombing of the MOVE house had been given by the City Medical Examiner‚Äôs Office to the Penn Museum for purposes of identification::: and that the remains have continued to be kept at the Museum.

We understand the importance of reuniting the remains with the family::: and we are working now to find a respectful::: consultative resolution.

As part of the actions recently announced in the Morton Collection Committee‚Äôs report::: we are reassessing our practices of collecting::: stewarding::: displaying::: and researching human remains.

In all of this::: we are constantly bearing in mind that human remains need to be treated with the dignity and respect that they deserve.

PENNTODAY.UPENN.EDU
Statement from the Penn Museum on the MOVE house remains | Penn Today

Statement from Penn President Amy Gutmann regarding the verdict in the Derek Chauvin trial

Today‚Äôs verdict is an important step towards justice in this case::: but we as a campus community and a country have much more to do in our work toward racial justice and healing.

Our thoughts are with Mr. Floyd‚Äôs family and we hope that the jury‚Äôs verdict brings them some measure of comfort. We must and we will continue to work with renewed resolve to ensure that the University and our nation move ever closer to fulfilling our pledge of liberty and justice for all.

We recognize the many questions about what role Penn will play in distributing vaccines to the Penn community. Penn‚Äôs Vaccine Response Team (VRT) is currently working on implementing a vaccine distribution plan to provide vaccine access to faculty::: staff::: postdocs::: and students.

The University has received authorization from the Philadelphia Department of Public Health (PDPH) to administer the vaccine on campus to eligible faculty::: staff::: postdocs::: and students.

During the COVID-19 pandemic::: our country has witnessed an alarming and deeply troubling surge of violence::: hatred and discrimination directed at Asians and Asian Americans. We write today to denounce this appalling prejudice and to assure our students::: faculty::: staff::: and postdocs of Asian descent that Penn is unwavering in our commitment to providing you with a safe::: welcoming::: and supportive campus environment.

We are enormously proud of the large::: vibrant::: and diverse Asian community at Penn. We are equally proud of the myriad contributions our Asian community make to the striking success of our University. Penn has numerous programs aimed at supporting our international and Asian American students. Just this past year::: we formed a Task Force on Support for Asian and Asian American Students and Scholars to coordinate and enhance support to members of the Penn community experiencing increased stigma::: bias::: discrimination::: and violence during the COVID-19 pandemic. We encourage all members of the Penn community to join the Task Force‚Äôs #FlattenTheHate Campaign.

As we look forward to the fall semester::: we want to share our current thinking so that students::: families::: faculty and staff can begin to make plans. With the widespread distribution of the COVID-19 vaccine now underway::: with projections of more ample supply in the several months ahead::: and with the many safeguards we have been able to establish on campus::: at this time we expect to be able to return to an in-person teaching::: research and residential environment for the fall of 2021. This will include the return to campus of staff who have been working remotely during the pandemic.

Specific details regarding the fall semester are still being developed and will be shared with students::: faculty::: staff and parents in the coming weeks. It will be necessary to remain vigilant and flexible in our planning::: as the pandemic could take unpredictable turns. column3:
> The current state-by-state winner-take-all
system of electing the President repeatedly generates unnecessary uncertainty and chaos.

Now we need to support and urge state legislators in states with the 74 more electoral votes needed::: to enact the National Popular Vote bill.

A different choice by 5:::229 voters in Arizona (11 electors)::: 5:::890 in Georgia (16)::: and 10:::342 in Wisconsin (10) would have defeated Biden -\-\ despite Biden's nationwide lead of more than 7 million. The Electoral College would have tied 269-269. Congress would have decided the election::: regardless of the popular vote in any state or throughout the country.

Each of these 21:::461 voters was 329 times more important than the more than 7 million.

It‚Äôs because of current state-by-state statewide winner-take-all
laws for Electoral College votes::: not mentioned::: much less endorsed::: in the Constitution.

In 2016::: Trump became President even though Clinton won the national popular vote by 2:::868:::518 votes.

Trump won the Presidency because he carried Michigan by 11:::000 votes::: Wisconsin by 23:::000 votes::: and Pennsylvania by 44:::000 votes.

Each of these 78:::000 votes was 36 times more important than Clinton's nationwide lead of 2:::868:::518 votes.

537 popular votes won Florida and the White House for Bush in 2000 despite Gore's lead of 537:::179 (1:::000 times more) popular votes nationwide.

The National Popular Vote bill is states with 270+ electoral votes agreeing to award their electoral votes to the winner of the most national popular votes.

All votes would be valued equally in presidential elections::: no matter where voters live.

column3:
Now we need to support and urge state legislators in states with the 74 more electoral votes needed::: to enact the National Popular Vote bill.

The current state-by-state winner-take-all
system of electing the President repeatedly generates unnecessary uncertainty and chaos.

Most Americans think it is wrong that the candidate with the most national popular votes can lose a presidential election.
We don't allow this in any other election in our representative republic.

The bill is 73% of the way to guaranteeing the majority of Electoral College votes and the presidency to the candidate who receives the most popular votes in the country.
The bill changes state statewide winner-take-all
laws (not mentioned in the U.S. Constitution::: but later enacted by 48 states)::: without changing anything in the Constitution::: using the built-in method that the Constitution provides for states to make changes.

States are agreeing to award their 270+ electoral votes to the winner of the most national popular votes.

All votes would be valued equally in presidential elections::: no matter where voters live.

column6:
In exactly one month from yesterday it will be 36 years to the day that the junior senator from Delaware visited and spoke to the Penn community::: on February 19::: 1985. To my knowledge::: this was his first time ever speaking at Penn.

As I had invited him::: I had the distinct pleasure of introducing the Senator in front of about 150 students in a law school lecture room. I kept my notes::: which I recently dug up along with these pictures::: and I closed my introduction of the Senator with these words:

‚Äúit has been said with ever more frequency that Joe Biden as that special combination of characteristics
perhaps best suited for the white house‚Äù.

The Senator::: whom I invited to speak on the topic of arms control::: arrived for a private dinner at La Terrasse the night before with visiting professor Flynt Leverett and six other students::: and we had a private session in advance of his speech::: where many of the photos below were taken. For the history buffs::: The Daily Pennsylvanian wrote two articles about this visit::: once in advance:

https://
dparchives.libra
ry.upenn.edu/
?a=d...
then in review of his speech:
https://
dparchives.libra
ry.upenn.edu/
?a=d...

I‚Äôve got some great photos of the visit::: but unfortunately this page won‚Äôt allow me to upload them. Check out my response to this same posting @pennarchives for the photos.

she was interrupted by attendee Robert Schuyler::: an archaeologist at the University of Pennsylvania (UPenn) and SHA president in 1982. Schuyler unmuted himself on Zoom and asked for the floor. He urged members to attend 2022‚Äôs in-person meeting in Philadelphia::: then asked how the pandemic had affected SHA‚Äôs membership renewal numbers.

‚ÄúThis is not the place for you to bring this up:::‚Äù Quinlan responded. Schuyler then raised his voice and said::: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry::: but I have freedom of speech and you‚Äôre not going to tell me this is not the place for me to bring this up.‚Äù

‚ÄúI am attempting to utilize the position the SHA gave me to speak about important topics [of accessibility and inclusion]:::‚Äù Quinlan said.

Schuyler then thrust his arm in the air and said::: ‚ÄúSieg heil to you.‚Äù

President Gutmann and Provost Pritchett shared their statement on regarding yesterday's assault on the Capitol.

"Nothing is more foundational to American democracy than respect for the peaceful transfer of power. Fueled by the dangerous propagation of falsehoods and disproven allegations::: a mob on Wednesday assaulted this bedrock value of American democracy::: storming our nation‚Äôs Capitol in an attempt to block the constitutionally mandated counting of certified electoral votes in our 2020 presidential election.

As citizens::: scholars::: teachers::: and university leaders dedicated to understanding::: defending and strengthening American constitutional democracy::: we join together with everyone who raises their voices and condemns threatening incitements and assaults on the political freedom of all citizens. We also join with our fellow Americans in praising those leaders of all parties who worked through the night to carry on the constitutional mission of recognizing the peaceful transfer of presidential power.

May we now continue to work across divides to strengthen and secure our constitutional democracy."
-Amy Gutmann::: President
Wendell Pritchett::: Provost

PENNTODAY.UPENN.EDU
Statement regarding the assault on the U.S. Capitol | Penn Today

column3:
I think Penn and other institutions concerned about energy and environmental consequences of ways of producing energy should do more to decrease their consumption of energy. For example::: I have seen the multiple outdoor electric heat lamps in front of the main entrance of HUP all running full blast while the outdoor temperature was in the 60s. There is a similarly power-hungry bunch of these heat lamps at the main entrance of the Perelman Center for Advanced Medicine. The Inn at Penn hotel also has electric outdoor heat lamps. I think that the percentage of these heat lamps being on should be cut back as outdoor temperature increases past some point::: and at least most of them should be off when the outdoor temperature is in the 60s. Also::: I think that during air conditioning season::: businesses and institutions should allow and encourage men in their offices (and classrooms and lecture halls) to dress with clothing as cooling as clothing that they allow women to wear::: including in the Wharton School. And even if a business or institution only purchases fossil-fuel-fre
e electricity::: if they use less electricity then this means more fossil-fuel-fre
e electricity on the market to displace someone else's use of electricity from fossil fuels. I have noticed that fossil-fuel-pow
ered generators are generally the ones that get cranked up and down in response to changes in demand::: as evidenced by percentages of electricity supply being from non-fossil-fuel
sources being higher in times of the year when demand is lower.

Penn Medicine's first COVID-19 vaccinations began this morning at Pennsylvania Hospital.

Penn Medicine
December 16::: 2020 at 9:55 AM ¬∑

Penn Medicine‚Äôs first COVID-19 vaccinations began this morning at Pennsylvania Hospital::: marking the latest inspirational milestone for our nation‚Äôs first hospital. Emergency department nurse Eric Young::: RN::: BSN::: who had just ended his night shift at the hospital::: was the first health system staff member to receive the vaccine ‚Äì to applause from those gathered.

Proudly administering the shot to Young was Joanne Ruggiero::: MSN::: MA::: his former nursing school study partner at LaSalle University::: who is now clinical director for Women‚Äôs Health and Behavioral Health.

Vaccinations will begin at other hospitals across the health system in the coming days. We are thrilled to be able to offer the vaccine to our #healthcareheroes. There are brighter days up ahead. #PennTogether #TogetherWeCan

athlete who was world renowned as an architect. To come to this table required big bucks - again like Ohio State or UCLA. So I leave donating to small amounts::: and to those who want buildings and professorships named after them. Other schools - like my grad school::: Dartmouth do it differently::: valuing participation as much as pocketbook. I do have some constructive recommendations

The CDC has updated its estimates of the Infection Fatality Rate:

AGE ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.. SURVIVAL RATE
0-19 ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶..‚Ä¶ 99.997%
20-49 ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.. 99.98%
50-69 ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.. 99.5%
70+ ‚Ä¶...‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ 94.6%

Note that the 70+ group has enhanced risk from ANY opportunistic infection::: even cold or flu. Finally::: note that the CDC‚Äôs newest numbers INCLUDE people with significant comorbidities. If you personally::: or your parents::: do not have these kinds of chronic life-threatenin
g problems::: your odds are much::: much better than even these numbers. What's there to be scared of? Go out and live!

In recent years::: we've seen a trend toward probabilistic political polls that tell us the percentage chance that a candidate will win the election. As happened with Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump in 2016::: often these numbers show a strong likelihood that one candidate will win::: despite the actual percentages of voters being quite close.

Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania Assistant Professor Yphtach Lelkes breaks down this polling problem::: and explains why this type of misleading polling leads to political hobbyism and can even swing the results of an election.

In short::: VOTE.

With less than a week until Election Day::: the dedicated student team at Penn Leads the Vote has been operating in overdrive::: ensuring that they‚Äôre doing all they can to get out the vote.

President Amy Gutmann and Provost Wendell Pritchett chatted virtually with the organization‚Äôs leaders::: thanking them for all their hard work. ‚ÄúIt is truly uplifting to know that you are using every possible::: every productive::: every important means to really make our democracy work for everybody:::‚Äù Gutmann said.

PENNTODAY.UPENN.EDU
Down to the wire with Penn Leads the Vote | Penn Today

We write to provide you with the University‚Äôs current plans for the spring semester::: which will begin on January 20::: 2021.

The current fall semester has given us essential information and insights into how best to manage campus life as the pandemic continues its worldwide spread. With a limited number of students on campus and in West Philadelphia this fall::: we have been able to successfully minimize risk to our community through effective testing and tracing systems::: rigorous enforcement of the guidelines enacted to protect the health of our community and::: most importantly::: the conscientious commitment of students::: faculty and staff::: for which we are grateful.

As we approach the spring semester::: we have been working with Penn Medicine to dramatically expand our testing capacity. With additional testing available::: we are confident that we can support increased numbers of students returning to campus in January.

Students who choose to return to campus will be able to engage in a variety of small-group interactions and have access to library study space::: outdoor athletic facilities::: and other extracurricular activities::: all subject to public health guidelines and our Student Campus Compact.

The hybrid educational experiences for all students in the spring are likely to be similar to this fall: most classes will be delivered remotely::: with limited exceptions::: including courses with clinical experiences and in-person research required for graduation.

Adherence to the guidelines for conduct during the pandemic as outlined in the Student Campus Compact will continue to be required of all students. Among other conditions outlined in the Compact::: students are required to receive a flu shot before their return. Proof of immunization to the flu will be a condition of attendance.

To maximize our ability to protect the community from the coronavirus::: all undergraduates will be required to be tested for COVID-19 twice per week upon their return to campus::: and all graduate and professional students engaged in research activities on campus or living in the area once per week.

Full announcement linked below.

PENNTODAY.UPENN.EDU
Planning for Penn's spring 2021 semester | Penn Today

Our community is grieving the loss of Walter Wallace::: Jr. His death is a tragedy on so many levels::: and a stark reminder of the life and death struggles faced by so many Black Philadelphians. This has been a year where we have witnessed the repeated violent deaths of people of color::: and struggled with the emotions and rage that stirred. But Walter Wallace‚Äôs death is particularly hard for all of us at Penn::: because it occurred in our West Philadelphia community. He was our neighbor. And his loss is felt profoundly.

It is at times like this that we need to be particularly mindful of taking care of each other::: and remembering our common bond as a community here in West Philadelphia. We know that this is a particularly fraught time for students::: faculty and staff of color. Words alone will not soothe their anguish::: but we want them to know of our unequivocal support in this difficult hour.

We are also mindful of the needs of our West Philadelphia neighbors. Recently we announced Penn Medicine‚Äôs commitment to help transform Mercy Catholic Medical Center to ensure the continuity of care for the West Philadelphia community. It is an initiative that will::: among many other things::: provide important behavioral health services for the neighborhood.

We also want to remind the campus community of the mental health and support services available here at Penn. There are many places to turn for help in times of stress and grief. In addition to those formal channels::: we urge you to look out for each other. There has never been a more important time to be personally supportive of friends::: colleagues and classmates.

These are difficult times::: where there are no easy solutions. Our thoughts are with the family of Walter Wallace::: Jr.::: and our hope is that no other families suffer as they have this week.

from
Amy Gutmann::: President
Wendell Pritchett::: Provost
Craig Carnaroli::: Executive Vice President

PENNTODAY.UPENN.EDU
A message to the Penn community regarding the death of Walter Wallace Jr. | Penn Today

"Emile" is a film tracing a year in the life of neuroscientist Emile Bruneau::: Ph.D.::: who recently passed away. In it::: he embraces a brain cancer (glioblastoma) diagnosis with surprising positivity and works to accelerate the timeline of his scientific mission: to use the tools of neuroscience and psychology to bring peace to groups of people who are in conflict.

Bruneau::: founder of the Peace and Conflict Neuroscience Lab at the University of Pennsylvania's Annenberg School for Communication::: has worked to find actionable strategies for healing the divisions between groups of people. His mission is to "put science to work for peace." Read more about his work at https://pcnl.asc.upenn.edu.

column3: Penn Vet I applaud your efforts. But let‚Äôs apply some math here. How many lantern flies are there? I‚Äôve personally seen thousands this year. Which means there‚Äôs most likely millions. How many millions I don‚Äôt know. Let‚Äôs say each lantern fly has 30 offspring. So next year. There‚Äôll be million more. And then 30 times that number the following year. An exponential increase. This is a industrial scale problem requiring an industrial scale solution. I hope your dogs don‚Äôt tire too easily.

Important Dates for the November 3 General Election
October 19 at 11:59 p.m: Deadline to register to vote or update voter registration.

October 27 at 5 p.m: Deadline sign up to vote by mail ballot (mail-in or absentee ballot).

November 3: Election Day

Polls are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m.
Last day to return your mail ballot:
By mail: Your mail ballot must be postmarked by 8 p.m. on Election Day and received by your county‚Äôs election office by 5 p.m. on November 6 to be counted.
In-person: You must return your mail ballot to your county‚Äôs election office or other designated location by 8 p.m. on Election Day.

column1:
Statement on the Passing of Ruth Bader Ginsburg
From Amy Gutmann

Friday we lost one of the most respected::: and most beloved::: jurists of our time. A brilliant and barrier-breaking leader::: Ruth Bader Ginsburg brought forth her fiery commitment to justice and equality with the truest grit possible. No one has ever worked more tirelessly and effectively to advance the equal status of women through the law. At the same time::: Justice Ginsburg championed the ethical principles of equal liberty and human rights::: advancing the cause of justice everywhere. Her quiet passion and relentless work broke through political as well as legal barriers previously unimaginable::: but always warranted::: including equal pay for equal work.

Justice Ginsburg was a pioneer and an inspiration. It was my honor to award her an honorary degree from Penn in 2007::: and just two years ago to have her back on campus at Penn Law to celebrate her 25 years on the Supreme Court. In response to a student‚Äôs question::: Justice Ginsburg explained why it was that young people gave her optimism for the future. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs in your hands to see which way our country goes:::‚Äù Justice Ginsburg said. Her greatest legacy is to inspire us all to continue breaking down barriers to equal justice.

https://bit.ly/2RJ1Neg

PENNTODAY.UPENN.EDU
Statement on the passing of Ruth Bader Ginsburg | Penn Today

column3:
Even when my poem is short:::
It is still full.
There are still all the parts I break into to give you a whole poem.
I am a son of the sun:::
I am not tied to tides caused by the moon:::
Just vast oceans of a truth that could not be solid enough to matter.
I could tell you my weight but it won‚Äôt matter because my weight is not the mass of my life:::
I have weighed that truth.
Just because I add friends on Facebook and Instagram::: it‚Äôs not the sum of my life.
My science teacher asked me if I believe there is life in Mars:::
I said I have witnessed what could alienate me.
I am not living my dreams but sometimes it feels like I am dreaming this life.
Maybe if really I could go back in time I would sleep different just to dream this life.
But everything happens in time::: for time::: because of time.
We can not free ourselves from time but we free ourselves time to time.
When you are a kid you eat on time until you are all grown and the thought of time eats you.
But there is no time for time to be itself in my mind.
I am old enough to age less and that‚Äôs more than timely.
Besides::: batteries go bad so time is not always correct

column1:
We write today with an enormous sense of sadness. It had been our fervent hope since the outset of the coronavirus pandemic that public health measures and an increased availability of testing would allow us to offer our undergraduates a hybrid learning experience this fall that::: by including more remote learning::: social distancing and other safety precautions::: would enable all the students who desired it the opportunity to live and learn on campus.

Unfortunately::: COVID-19 continues to spread at an alarming rate across the country::: with approximately 2 million new cases reported over just the past month. Thus::: based on the advice of the leading health experts at Penn Medicine and on current public health restrictions::: with the full support of the Penn Board of Trustees::: we must share the deeply disappointing news that with only very limited exceptions for international students and those students dealing with significant housing or personal hardships::: we will not be able to accommodate undergraduate students in University housing.

Additionally::: we have determined to make tuition and fee adjustments for the fall semester. Tuition for the fall semester will be rolled back by 3.9%::: thus freezing tuition at last year‚Äôs rate::: and the General Fee will be reduced for the fall semester by 10%. Housing and dining fees that have been paid by students will be credited or refunded in full::: consistent with the methodology used in the spring.

Read the full statement in Penn Today.

PENNTODAY.UPENN.EDU
Revision to fall semester plans regarding on-campus housing::: tuition::: and fees | Penn Today

column30:
It is with great regret that I believe Penn has handled this all wrong. They have known for weeks that the numbers had increased in some states. If that was the rationale for concluding that they could no longer offer the hybrid model::: they could have communicated that much earlier. My sense is Penn‚Äôs administration was never comfortable with the hybrid model::: but grappled with a significant portion of the student body and their parents who wanted on campus learning. Unfortunately::: for many of us::: it is very difficult to justify a Penn tuition where it is providing a University of Phoenix education (no slight on that institution-onl
y that it is an online school) and our students are deprived of the education they signed up for‚Äîa high quality in-person experience that allows for interactions with professors and other bright peers.

column40: What is 10% of the General Fee? What is covered by the 90% still being paid. While I tend to agree that not having students on campus is probably the correct decision::: does the 3.9% tuition reduction truly represent the operational savings of having all instruction online? Has Penn done such an analysis? They are saying that last year‚Äòs tuition rate which was obviously calculated with no consideration for all online courses is the cost for this year. With barely any inflation::: how was the 3.9% increase justified in the first place? These comments are not limited to Penn - they are representative of all ‚Äúelite‚Äù universities who for years have been successful at increasing costs at rates far above inflation. Would these reductions have even taken place if the school had not decided to have only remote instruction?

Renewable Hydrogen: The Future of Storage and Fuel of the Future?
column3: Will they go away from using platinum as a catalyst?
column4:
Green hydrogen is the most valuable commodity. It has the greatest energy density of any fuel::: so it does far more work than natural gas as it would be compressed::: giving it favorable parity (work to volume ratios).

Match to sustained wind streams::: either over the plains states or offshore::: and cash in. The US is said to be the Saudi Arabia of wind::: so hydrogen can build out accordingly.

The models for hydrogen are not yet set. Creating at ports for MHE or export::: or onsite::: would seem to be best::: for the time being.

Otherwise::: send forward by pipeline.

Hydrogen can also be made nightly::: when demand is low::: or when there are storms::: when there are conditions ripe for yielding more kinetic energy for wind turbines.

Beyond that::: the US has massive waste in its national grid system::: well over 10 quadrillion BTUs::: annually.

Since this energy is currently rejected energy::: the costs are zero marginal::: meaning that costs of H2 streams would be primarily associated with capital.

Capture portions of that as recycled energy::: i.e. as hydrogen. Hydrogen can replace fossil fuel in any application::: and be turned into many different key chemicals.

It does not hurt that the hydrogen economy is the key to solving climate change::: as well.

Europe is currently gearing their natural gas grid to become a hydrogen one::: so we have quite a bit of catching up to do.

There is no need to store all hydrogen::: so the figure stated is inaccurate. Europe will just keep hydrogen in pipelines::: a volume to match three months of use.

Hydrogen::: static type::: is to be stored in abandoned salt mines or fallow gas fields::: so the space available for strategic or collateral type storage is quite high in the US.

You can bank on vaulted (static) hydrogen::: so it is hard to say that this is a trivial innovation set in the energy sector.

column3: In my family::: there was never any controversy over the bombings. My dad::: a marine::: had already taken four islands in the Pacific. He had been promoted to the highest rank of sargent and was training to drive his amphibious tractor to the beach of one of the major Japanese Islands. He would have been part of a chevron of boats which were to be the first to leave for the beach. He expected to die. I don't know if it was morally defensible. I don't know if the Japanese were ready to surrender. I do know my dad believed these bombs saved his life.
column4: so sad!
column5: In the last 75 years::: how many World Wars have there been? Who destroyed the Japanese Navy? Who destroyed the Japanese Air Force? Who defeated::: despite insane tactics and in horrific environments::: the Japanese Army? How many "innocent noncombatants" would have died if the mainland had to invaded? During the war::: did the Japanese ever surrender when all common sense told them to? When did the Soviets enter the war against Japan? The exact day and time are a joke! Thank God Harry Truman had the courage to do what had to be done. I have nothing but contempt for the self-righteous people who pretend to have courage after the fighting has ended::: and the danger has passed. If Japan had won the war::: would the U.S. be thriving as well as Japan and Germany are today? The last paragraph here is pathetic!
